summaries.title: Article 1: Subject matter and scope

summaries.title: 1.This Regulation lays down uniform rules to address the misuse of relevant information society services for online child sexual abuse in the internal market.
summaries.summary: Rules to prevent and combat online child sexual abuse across EU digital services.

summaries.title: CHAPTER II - OBLIGATIONS OF PROVIDERS OF RELEVANT INFORMATION SOCIETY SERVICES TO PREVENT AND COMBAT ONLINE CHILD SEXUAL ABUSE
summaries.summary: Rules for online platforms to detect and stop child abuse.

summaries.title: Section 1: Risk assessment and mitigation obligations
summaries.summary: Assess risks and implement mitigation measures.

summaries.title: Article 3: Risk assessment
summaries.summary: Methods to identify, analyze and evaluate potential hazards and threats.

summaries.title: 1.Providers of hosting services and providers of interpersonal communications services shall identify, analyse and assess, for each such service that they offer, the risk of use of the service for the purpose of online child sexual abuse.
summaries.summary: Service providers must assess child sexual abuse risks in their hosting and communications platforms.

summaries.title: 2.When carrying out a risk assessment, the provider shall take into account, in particular:
summaries.summary: Risk assessments must consider specific factors and details when evaluating potential hazards.

summaries.title: (a)any previously identified instances of use of its services for the purpose...
summaries.summary: Report past cases where services were used for online child sexual abuse.

summaries.title: (b)the existence and implementation by the provider of a policy and the avail...
summaries.summary: Provider must implement policies and tools to prevent child sexual abuse online.

summaries.title: (c)the manner in which users use the service and the impact thereof on that r...
summaries.summary: How users interact with service and resulting effects on risk.

summaries.title: (d)the manner in which the provider designed and operates the service, includ...
summaries.summary: How provider designs and runs service, including business model and processes.

summaries.title: (e)with respect to the risk of solicitation of children:
summaries.summary: Protect children from being solicited.

summaries.title: (i) the extent to which the service is used or is likely to be used by children;
summaries.summary: Assess how many children currently use or may use the service.

summaries.title: (ii) where the service is used by children, the different age groups of the c...
summaries.summary: Identify child user age groups and assess solicitation risks in service features.

summaries.title: (iii) the availability of functionalities creating or reinforcing the risk of...
summaries.summary: Features that let adults search for, contact, or share media with children privately.

summaries.title: 3.The provider may request the EU Centre to perform an analysis of representative, anonymized data samples to identify potential online child sexual abuse, to support the risk assessment.
summaries.summary: Providers can ask EU Centre to analyze anonymous data samples for child abuse detection.

summaries.title: 4.The provider shall carry out the first risk assessment by [Date of application of this Regulation + 3 months] or, where the provider did not offer the service in the Union by [Date of application of this Regulation], by three months from the date at which the provider started offering the service in the Union.
summaries.summary: Complete first risk assessment within 3 months of regulation start or service launch.

summaries.title: (a)for a service which is subject to a detection order issued in accordance w...
summaries.summary: Update risk assessment two months before detection order expires.

summaries.title: (b)the Coordinating Authority of establishment may require the provider to up...
summaries.summary: Authority can require earlier risk assessment update if child abuse risk changes substantially.

summaries.title: 5.The risk assessment shall include an assessment of any potential remaining risk that, after taking the mitigation measures pursuant to Article 4, the service is used for the purpose of online child sexual abuse.
summaries.summary: Assess residual risk of child sexual abuse after implementing mitigation measures.

summaries.title: 6.The Commission, in cooperation with Coordinating Authorities and the EU Centre and after having conducted a public consultation, may issue guidelines on the application of paragraphs 1 to 5, having due regard in particular to relevant technological developments and to the manners in which the services covered by those provisions are offered and used.
summaries.summary: Commission may issue guidelines after public consultation on applying technology-related service provisions.

summaries.title: Article 4: Risk mitigation
summaries.summary: Methods to identify, assess and reduce potential threats and dangers.

summaries.title: 1.Providers of hosting services and providers of interpersonal communications services shall take reasonable mitigation measures, tailored to the risk identified pursuant to Article 3, to minimise that risk. Such measures shall include some or all of the following:
summaries.summary: Hosting and communication providers must implement risk mitigation measures based on Article 3.

summaries.title: (a)adapting, through appropriate technical and operational measures and staff...
summaries.summary: Adapt content moderation, systems, operations, staffing, and terms to meet requirements.

summaries.title: (b)reinforcing the provider’s internal processes or the internal supervision ...
summaries.summary: Strengthen provider's internal processes and service supervision.

summaries.title: (c)initiating or adjusting cooperation, in accordance with competition law, w...
summaries.summary: Cooperate with hosting providers, authorities, and trusted organizations while following competition laws.

summaries.title: 2.The mitigation measures shall be:
summaries.summary: Mitigation measures must effectively address risks while being proportionate, non-discriminatory, and regularly reviewed.

summaries.title: (a)effective in mitigating the identified risk;
summaries.summary: Must effectively reduce known risks.

summaries.title: (b)targeted and proportionate in relation to that risk, taking into account, ...
summaries.summary: Actions must match risk level, considering severity, resources, and user count.

summaries.title: (c)applied in a diligent and non-discriminatory manner, having due regard, in...
summaries.summary: Apply measures fairly and carefully while considering impacts on everyone's fundamental rights.

summaries.title: (d)introduced, reviewed, discontinued or expanded, as appropriate, each time ...
summaries.summary: Review and update measures within three months of each risk assessment.

summaries.title: 3.Providers of interpersonal communications services that have identified, pursuant to the risk assessment conducted or updated in accordance with Article 3, a risk of use of their services for the purpose of the solicitation of children, shall take the necessary age verification and age assessment measures to reliably identify child users on their services, enabling them to take the mitigation measures.
summaries.summary: Communication services must verify user ages if child solicitation risks are identified.

summaries.title: 4.Providers of hosting services and providers of interpersonal communications services shall clearly describe in their terms and conditions the mitigation measures that they have taken. That description shall not include information that may reduce the effectiveness of the mitigation measures.
summaries.summary: Hosting providers must describe safety measures in terms, excluding details that compromise effectiveness.

summaries.title: 5.The Commission, in cooperation with Coordinating Authorities and the EU Centre and after having conducted a public consultation, may issue guidelines on the application of paragraphs 1, 2, 3 and 4, having due regard in particular to relevant technological developments and in the manners in which the services covered by those provisions are offered and used.
summaries.summary: Commission may issue guidelines after consultation, considering tech developments and service usage.

summaries.title: Article 5: Risk reporting
summaries.summary: Financial risk disclosure requirements and reporting standards for organizations.

summaries.title: 1.Providers of hosting services and providers of interpersonal communications services shall transmit, by three months from the date referred to in Article 3(4), to the Coordinating Authority of establishment a report specifying the following:
summaries.summary: Service providers must submit report to Coordinating Authority within three months.

summaries.title: (a)the process and the results of the risk assessment conducted or updated pu...
summaries.summary: Document risk assessment process, results, and any remaining risks identified.

summaries.title: (b)any mitigation measures taken pursuant to Article 4.
summaries.summary: Report mitigation actions taken under Article 4.

summaries.title: 2.Within three months after receiving the report, the Coordinating Authority of establishment shall assess it and determine, on that basis and taking into account any other relevant information available to it, whether the risk assessment has been carried out or updated and the mitigation measures have been taken in accordance with the requirements of Articles 3 and 4.
summaries.summary: Authority must verify risk assessment and mitigation compliance within 3 months of report receipt.

summaries.title: 3.Where necessary for that assessment, that Coordinating Authority may require further information from the provider, within a reasonable time period set by that Coordinating Authority. That time period shall not be longer than two weeks.
summaries.summary: Authority can request additional information from provider within maximum two-week deadline.

summaries.title: 4.Without prejudice to Articles 7 and 27 to 29, where the requirements of Articles 3 and 4 have not been met, that Coordinating Authority shall require the provider to re-conduct or update the risk assessment or to introduce, review, discontinue or expand, as applicable, the mitigation measures, within a reasonable time period set by that Coordinating Authority. That time period shall not be longer than one month.
summaries.summary: Authority requires providers update risk assessment or mitigation measures within one month.

summaries.title: 5.Providers shall, when transmitting the report to the Coordinating Authority of establishment in accordance with paragraph 1, transmit the report also to the EU Centre.
summaries.summary: Providers must send reports to both Coordinating Authority and EU Centre.

summaries.title: 6.Providers shall, upon request, transmit the report to the providers of software application stores, insofar as necessary for the assessment referred to in Article 6(2). Where necessary, they may remove confidential information from the reports.
summaries.summary: Send reports to app stores when requested; confidential information can be removed.

summaries.title: Article 6: Obligations for software application stores
summaries.summary: App store rules for transparency, security and fair business practices.

summaries.title: 1.Providers of software application stores shall:
summaries.summary: App store providers must follow these rules.

summaries.summary: Assess if apps could be used to solicit children, working with app providers.

summaries.title: (b)take reasonable measures to prevent child users from accessing the softwar...
summaries.summary: Prevent children from accessing software apps with high risk of child solicitation.

summaries.title: (c)take the necessary age verification and age assessment measures to reliabl...
summaries.summary: Verify and assess user ages to identify children on the service.

summaries.title: 2.In assessing the risk referred to in paragraph 1, the provider shall take into account all the available information, including the results of the risk assessment conducted or updated pursuant to Article 3.
summaries.summary: Provider must consider all available information and risk assessment results from Article 3.

summaries.title: 3.Providers of software application stores shall make publicly available information describing the process and criteria used to assess the risk and describing the measures referred to in paragraph 1. That description shall not include information that may reduce the effectiveness of the assessment of those measures.
summaries.summary: App store providers must publish risk assessment process details without compromising security measures.

summaries.title: 4.The Commission, in cooperation with Coordinating Authorities and the EU Centre and after having conducted a public consultation, may issue guidelines on the application of paragraphs 1, 2 and 3, having due regard in particular to relevant technological developments and to the manners in which the services covered by those provisions are offered and used.
summaries.summary: Commission may issue guidelines after consultation, considering tech developments and service usage.

summaries.title: Section 2: Detection obligations
summaries.summary: Providers must detect and report online child sexual abuse content.

summaries.summary: Detection orders: legal process for monitoring criminal communications/activities

summaries.summary: Coordinating Authority can request courts to order service providers to detect child abuse content.

summaries.title: 2.The Coordinating Authority of establishment shall, before requesting the issuance of a detection order, carry out the investigations and assessments necessary to determine whether the conditions of paragraph 4 have been met.
summaries.summary: Authority must investigate and verify paragraph 4 conditions before requesting detection order.

summaries.summary: Authority must act when paragraph 4 conditions are satisfied.

summaries.summary: EU Centre must review draft request and provide opinion within 4 weeks.

summaries.title: (a)draft an implementation plan setting out the measures it envisages taking ...

summaries.title: (b)where the draft implementation plan concerns an intended detection order c...
summaries.summary: Conduct data protection assessment and consultation for new child solicitation detection orders.

summaries.title: (c)where point (b) applies, or where the conditions of Articles 35 and 36 of ...
summaries.summary: Adjust implementation plan based on data protection assessment and authority opinion.

summaries.title: (d)submit to that Coordinating Authority the implementation plan, where appli...
summaries.summary: Submit implementation plan with data protection opinion to Coordinating Authority for review.

summaries.title: 4.The Coordinating Authority of establishment shall request the issuance of the detection order, and the competent judicial authority or independent administrative authority shall issue the detection order where it considers that the following conditions are met:
summaries.summary: Coordinating Authority requests detection order; judicial/administrative authority issues if conditions met.

summaries.title: (a)there is evidence of a significant risk of the service being used for the ...
summaries.summary: Evidence shows significant risk of service enabling online child sexual abuse.

summaries.title: (b)the reasons for issuing the detection order outweigh negative consequences...
summaries.summary: Benefits of detection order must exceed harm to affected parties' rights and interests.

summaries.summary: Detection orders for new child abuse material require specific risk conditions.

summaries.title: (a)the provider qualifies as a provider of interpersonal communication services;

summaries.title: (d)the specific service in respect of which the detection order is issued and...

summaries.title: Article 9: Redress, information, reporting and modification of detection orders
summaries.summary: Detection orders: rules for appeals, transparency, and making changes.

summaries.title: 1.Providers of hosting services and providers of interpersonal communications services that have received a detection order, as well as users affected by the measures taken to execute it, shall have a right to effective redress. That right shall include the right to challenge the detection order before the courts of the Member State of the competent judicial authority or independent administrative authority that issued the detection order.
summaries.summary: Service providers and affected users can challenge detection orders in issuing member state's courts.

summaries.title: 2.When the detection order becomes final, the competent judicial authority or independent administrative authority that issued the detection order shall, without undue delay, transmit a copy thereof to the Coordinating Authority of establishment. The Coordinating Authority of establishment shall then, without undue delay, transmit a copy thereof to all other Coordinating Authorities through the system established in accordance with Article 39(2).
summaries.summary: Authority must share final detection orders with Coordinating Authority, who distributes to others.

summaries.title: 3.Where the period of application of the detection order exceeds 12 months, or six months in the case of a detection order concerning the solicitation of children, the Coordinating Authority of establishment shall require the provider to report to it on the execution of the detection order at least once, halfway through the period of application.

summaries.title: 2.The Court of Justice of the European Union shall have jurisdiction to give judgment pursuant to any arbitration clause contained in a contract concluded by the EU Centre.

summaries.title: 3.In the case of non-contractual liability, the EU Centre shall, in accordance with the general principles common to the laws of the Member States, make good any damage caused by its departments or by its staff in the performance of their duties.

summaries.title: 4.The Court of Justice of the European Union shall have jurisdiction in disputes over compensation for damages referred to in paragraph 3.

summaries.title: 5.The personal liability of its staff towards the Centre shall be governed by the provisions laid down in the Staff Regulations or Conditions of Employment applicable to them.

summaries.title: 2.The Member State where the seat of the EU Centre is located shall provide the best possible conditions to ensure the smooth and efficient functioning of the EU Centre, including multilingual, European-oriented schooling and appropriate transport connections.

Those safeguards shall ensure, in particular, that the data can be accessed and processed only for the purpose for which it is stored, that a high level of security is achieved and that the information is deleted when no longer necessary for that purpose. They shall regularly review those safeguards and adjust them where necessary.

summaries.title: Article 84: Transparency reporting
summaries.summary: Digital platforms must regularly publish data about content moderation decisions.

summaries.title: 1.Each provider of relevant information society services shall draw up an annual report on its activities under this Regulation. That report shall compile the information referred to in Article 83(1). The providers shall, by 31 January of every year subsequent to the year to which the report relates, make the report available to the public and communicate it to the Coordinating Authority of establishment, the Commission and the EU Centre.
summaries.summary: Service providers must submit public annual reports by January 31 to EU authorities.

summaries.title: 2.Each Coordinating Authority shall draw up an annual report on its activities under this Regulation. That report shall compile the information referred to in Article 83(2). It shall, by 31 March of every year subsequent to the year to which the report relates, make the report available to the public and communicate it to the Commission and the EU Centre.
summaries.summary: Coordinating Authorities must submit public annual activity reports by March 31 to Commission and EU Centre.

summaries.title: 3.Where a Member State has designated several competent authorities pursuant to Article 25, it shall ensure that the Coordinating Authority draws up a single report covering the activities of all competent authorities under this Regulation and that the Coordinating Authority receives all relevant information and support needed to that effect from the other competent authorities concerned.
summaries.summary: Coordinating Authority must create single report combining all competent authorities' activities.

summaries.title: 4.The EU Centre, working in close cooperation with the Coordinating Authorities, shall draw up an annual report on its activities under this Regulation. That report shall also compile and analyse the information contained in the reports referred to in paragraphs 2 and 3. The EU Centre shall, by 30 June of every year subsequent to the year to which the report relates, make the report available to the public and communicate it to the Commission.
summaries.summary: EU Centre must publish annual public report by June 30, analyzing activities and data.

summaries.title: 5.The annual transparency reports referred to in paragraphs 1, 2 and 3 shall not include any information that may prejudice ongoing activities for the assistance to victims or the prevention, detection, investigation or prosecution of child sexual abuse offences. They shall also not contain any personal data.
summaries.summary: Annual transparency reports must exclude sensitive case details and personal data.

summaries.title: 6.The Commission shall be empowered to adopt delegated acts in accordance with Article 86 in order to supplement this Regulation with the necessary templates and detailed rules concerning the form, precise content and other details of the reports and the reporting process pursuant to paragraphs 1, 2 and 3.
summaries.summary: Commission can create templates and rules for reporting requirements under Article 86.

summaries.title: Article 85: Evaluation
summaries.summary: Assessment and measurement of performance, outcomes, and effectiveness.

summaries.title: 1.By [five years after the entry into force of this Regulation], and every five years thereafter, the Commission shall evaluate this Regulation and submit a report on its application to the European Parliament and the Council.
summaries.summary: Commission must evaluate regulation and report to Parliament every five years.

summaries.title: 2.By [five years after the entry into force of this Regulation], and every five years thereafter, the Commission shall ensure that an evaluation in accordance with Commission guidelines of the EU Centre’s performance in relation to its objectives, mandate, tasks and governance and location is carried out. The evaluation shall, in particular, address the possible need to modify the tasks of the EU Centre, and the financial implications of any such modification.
summaries.summary: Commission must evaluate EU Centre's performance and tasks every five years.

summaries.title: 3.On the occasion of every second evaluation referred to in paragraph 2, the results achieved by the EU Centre shall be assessed, having regard to its objectives and tasks, including an assessment of whether the continuation of the EU Centre is still justified with regard to those objectives and tasks.
summaries.summary: Every second evaluation must assess if EU Centre's results justify its continued existence.

summaries.title: 4.The Commission shall report to the European Parliament and the Council the findings of the evaluation referred to in paragraph 3. The findings of the evaluation shall be made public.
summaries.summary: Commission must report evaluation findings to Parliament, Council and make them public.

summaries.title: 5.For the purpose of carrying out the evaluations referred to in paragraphs 1, 2 and 3, the Coordinating Authorities and Member States and the EU Centre shall provide information to the Commission at its request.
summaries.summary: Authorities must provide requested information to Commission for evaluations in paragraphs 1-3.

summaries.title: 6.In carrying out the evaluations referred to in paragraphs 1, 2 and 3, the Commission shall take into account the relevant evidence at its disposal.
summaries.summary: Commission must use available relevant evidence when conducting evaluations from paragraphs 1-3.

summaries.title: 7.Where appropriate, the reports referred to in paragraphs 1 and 4 shall be accompanied by legislative proposals.
summaries.summary: Reports must include legislative proposals when needed.

summaries.title: Article 86: Exercise of the delegation
summaries.summary: EU rules for delegating and revoking Commission's legislative powers.

summaries.title: 1.The power to adopt delegated acts is conferred on the Commission subject to the conditions laid down in this Article.
summaries.summary: Commission can adopt delegated acts under conditions specified in this article.

summaries.title: 2.The power to adopt delegated acts referred to in Articles 3, 8, 13, 14, 17, 47 and 84 shall be conferred on the Commission for an indeterminate period of time from [date of adoption of the Regulation].
summaries.summary: Commission gets permanent power to adopt delegated acts under specified articles.

summaries.title: 3.The delegation of power referred to in Articles 3, 8, 13, 14, 17, 47 and 84 may be revoked at any time by the European Parliament or by the Council. A decision to revoke shall put an end to the delegation of the power specified in that decision. It shall take effect the day after the publication of the decision in the Official Journal of the European Union or at a later date specified therein. It shall not affect the validity of any delegated acts already in force.
summaries.summary: Parliament or Council can revoke delegated powers in Articles 3,8,13,14,17,47,84. Previous acts remain valid.

summaries.title: 4.Before adopting a delegated act, the Commission shall consult experts designated by each Member State in accordance with the principles laid down in the Inter-institutional Agreement of 13 April 2016 on Better Law-Making.
summaries.summary: Commission must consult Member State experts before adopting delegated acts.

summaries.title: 5.As soon as it adopts a delegated act, the Commission shall notify it simultaneously to the European Parliament and to the Council.
summaries.summary: Commission must notify Parliament and Council immediately after adopting delegated acts.

summaries.title: 6.A delegated act adopted pursuant to Articles 3, 8, 13, 14, 17, 47 and 84 shall enter into force only if no objection has been expressed either by the European Parliament or the Council within a period of two months of notification of that act to the European Parliament and the Council or if, before the expiry of that period, the European Parliament and the Council have both informed the Commission that they will not object. That period shall be extended by two months at the initiative of the European Parliament or of the Council.
summaries.summary: Delegated acts require no Parliament/Council objection within 2 months; period extendable by 2 months.

summaries.title: Article 87: Committee procedure

summaries.title: 1.For the purposes of the adoption of the implementing acts referred to in Article 39(4), the Commission shall be assisted by a committee. That committee shall be a committee within the meaning of Regulation (EU) No 182/2011.
